awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II: International Blockchain-Backed Financial Transactions in Low-Bandwidth Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project is to facilitate access to banking services through use of blockchain/distributed ledger technology, even with limited internet access. The proposed technology can make transfers more affordable and convenient. Digitizing transfers increases speed, reduces exchange and transfer fees, and lowers the risk associated with carrying cash.  This proposed technology enables access for the 13 million people currently underserved by the financial industry.  If successful, this technology could improve efficiency and resilience of transfers worldwide. The project's anticipated results include 60% cost reduction compared to traditional transfer systems, <30 second transaction completions, and an anticipated 0% fraud rate.

This SBIR Phase II project proposes to research and develop a blockchain-based solution to store, send, and make transfers without a smartphone or internet. The proposed core technology includes a blockchain back-end that powers an Unstructured Supplementary Service Data (USSD) front-end, allowing mobile devices to securely send and receive data without an internet connection. This project’s intellectual merit lies in (1) developing the first-of-its-kind blockchain-based system for international transactions with access even in low bandwidth/no bandwidth environments; (2) creating a digital identity protocol that is distributed, accessible offline, and usable by any entity without exposing personally identifiable information (PII); and (3) developing the first machine learning-based microlending algorithms using offline behaviors to predict, prompt, and automate actions. 

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Leaf Global Fintech built its novel blockchain platform to allow refugees and migrants to store and move money across borders, even in offline environments. The SBIR Phase II project expanded the existing infrastructure and product suite to support other financial needs of its initial customers. During the SBIR Phase II grant, Leaf Global Fintech Corporation was acquired by IDT Corporation. IDT Corporation (NYSE: IDT) is a global provider of fintech, cloud communications, and traditional communications services. The acquisition provides the opportunity to deploy Leaf globally through the worldwide network of IDT and leverage its money remittance services as a licensed Money Services Business (MSB) in the US. The acquisition also helped solidify the commercialization potential of the wallet technology.

During the grant period, Leaf expanded its wallet services substantially. Through integrations with locally licensed payment providers across Africa, Leaf was able to expand geographically from three countries in January of 2022 to ten countries in 2023 with its full suite of wallet services, including cash-in, cash-out, exchange, peer-to-peer, airtime purchases, and the Leaf Loans product as a beta version. Leaf grew its customer base from 7,381 customers to 55,773 customers in the same period and achieved 142,811 downloads with 8.96% coming from the Apple Store and 91.04% from the Google Play Store. Leaf processed an average of $7,753 per month at the beginning of the grant period and grew to a peak of $2,818,896 in 2023. The extensive growth in transactions and customers demonstrated that the Stellar wallet infrastructure could scale commercially. 

The Leaf team also completed the identity management project and developed an initial product for verifying the identities of customers across business lines at IDT. The Leaf team designed, built, and deployed a lending product with 105 users. A metadata-based lending algorithm was created, and one of the data models generated a repayment rate of 91.70%, demonstrating the commercial viability of the microlending product bundled with the wallet application.

 


Last Modified: 04/30/2024
Modified by: Nathaniel Robinson
